other_tests.findings: Diffuse infiltration of the adenohypophysis by numerous lymphocytes with occasional plasma cells and macrophages. No giant cells or granulomas were identified. No adenoma was identified.
other_tests.changes_over_time: Postoperatively, complaints of headaches, galactorrhea, and oligomenorrhea resolved. Serum PRL levels normalized to 27 mg/L, 17 mg/L, and 10 mg/L on the first, second, and third postoperative days, respectively. A 3-month postoperative MRI scan was normal. Continues to have normal pituitary and menstrual function with no requirement for hormone replacement after 6 years of follow-up.

other_tests.findings: Necrotizing granulomatous inflammation with variable numbers of plasma cells and foamy histiocytes with vacuolated cytoplasm. Areas of old hemorrhage with hemosiderin deposition were present.
other_tests.changes_over_time: Postoperative MRI showed significant resolution of the lesion. Six months later, headaches returned and MRI scan showed recurrence of the lesion. After treatment with corticosteroids, a follow-up MRI showed complete resolution of the pituitary lesion.

other_tests.findings: Chronic hypophysitis with fibrosis, lymphoplasmacytic infiltration, necrosis, hemorrhage, hemosiderin deposition, and foamy histiocytes. No evidence of an adenoma or cyst wall remnants.
other_tests.changes_over_time: Postoperatively, PRL levels normalized to 11 mg/L without dopaminergic inhibition. Two years later, continues to have normal pituitary function, including PRL levels (10 mg/L) and regular menstrual function.
